The second C−H bond cleavage in methane to form methylene (CH2*) from methyl (CH3*) is the rate-limiting step for the direct non-oxidative methane coupling to ethylene over gallium-nitride catalysts. Herein, we use isotope labelled experiments, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), 13C solid state-NMR, as well as kinetic modelling to elucidate the reaction mechanism. Our experiments showed that supported GaN/SBA-15 had more aliphatic surface intermediates (CH3* and CH2*) than unsupported GaN catalysts, which had higher amounts of aromatics intermediates and coke deposition. Isotope labelling experiments and the kinetic study confirmed that the most likely pathway is via the fast abstraction of the first H from CH4 to form methyl (CH3*) surface intermediates, followed by the slow second C−H bond cleavage to form methylene (CH2*) and subsequent coupling to ethylene. The intrinsic activation energy predicted by kinetic modelling was rather low at around 20 kJ mol−1. Graphical Abstract ga1 Keywords Methane activation Gallium nitride Kinetic isotope effect DRIFTS Kinetic modelling Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Much effort has been made to replace petroleum feedstock with natural gas and shale gas to produce chemical building blocks. The direct oxidative and non-oxidative conversion of methane is especially of great interest. The oxidative coupling of methane is not limited by thermodynamics; however, overoxidation of the reactive product (e.g., C2H4) to CO2 and H2O is a huge challenge. Methane aromatization over various bifunctional Mo-containing zeolites is the most studied pathway for the thermodynamically limited direct non-oxidative route [1–5]. In contrast, studies on the non-oxidative coupling to C2 hydrocarbons (ethylene and ethane) are scarce and usually carried out over conventional bimetallic Pt catalysts (e.g., Pt-Sn, Pt-Bi) supported on SiO2 and ZSM-5 [6,7] or over Fe/SiO2 catalyst [8]. Unfortunately, Pt-Sn and Fe/SiO2 have a rather broad product distribution (ethylene, naphthalene, ethane, benzene), while over Pt-Bi catalyst, ethane rather than ethylene is formed. In detail, Gerceker et al. [7] reported a CH4 conversion of max 0.3% with hydrocarbon selectivities (excluding coke) of 70–90% C2H4, 5–15% C2H6, 5–20% C10H8 and 0–5% C6H6 with carbon deposition of 25–120 mgC gcat –1 over Pt-Sn catalysts at 700 °C and a methane space velocity of 21–42 mLN min–1 gcat –1. Over iron-modified silica (Fe@SiO2) catalyst, reaction temperatures of at least 950 °C are required for the non-oxidative methane conversion, in which methane is first activated over the iron side to form methyl radicals (·CH3) that couple in the gas phase to ethane [8,9]. By means of operando photoelectron photoion coincidence spectroscopy and time-of-flight (TOF) mass spectra analysis, Puente-Urbina et al. [9] showed that ethane is the further transformed ethyl, ethylene and via radical-mediated gas-phase reactions to other hydrocarbon species C2–C6 as well as higher molecular weight hydrocarbons. However, the proposed reaction mechanism and gas-phase intermediates are only valid for high temperatures (945–1400 °C). In our previous works, we have shown that gallium nitride is active toward the non-oxidative CH4 activation [10–13]. We reported a CH4 conversion of 0.5% with hydrocarbon selectivities (excluding coke) of 97–99% C2H4, 0.1–2% C3H6 and < 0.2% C6H6 and a carbon deposition of 4–20 mgC gcat –1 over GaN/SBA-15 catalyst at 700 °C and a methane space velocity of 40 mLN min–1 gcat –1. Also, we could show catalyst stability of 100 h with an overall ethylene selectivity of around 70 mol% (balance coke)[14]. In addition, the regeneration capability and reusability of gallium nitride (GaN) catalyst have been shown in which the coked catalyst can be regenerated with air at 500 °C followed by re-nitridation of the surface Ga2O3 back to the active GaN sites [14]. Using density functional theory modelling, we suggested that CH4 dissociatively adsorbs over GaN via the alkyl mechanism (formation of H3C−Ga·N−H) and that the second C−H bond cleavage from CH3* to CH2* is the rate-determining step toward the formation of C2H4 [11]. However, the surface intermediates and reaction mechanism with the corresponding kinetic description are yet unknown, especially for temperatures well below 800 °C. Herein, we shed light on the conversion pathway via kinetic isotope (CH4, CH3D, CD4, and 13CH4) exchange experiments with detailed mass spectra analysis, in-situ DRIFTS analysis, as well as 13C solid-state NMR catalyst characterization and kinetic modelling. Other catalyst characterizations such as TEM, XRD, and surface areas have been reported in [10,12,14]. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation Two types of catalysts were synthesized and used in this study; an unsupported GaN and GaN supported on SBA-15 with a Ga target loading of 16 wt%. 2.1.1 Unsupported catalyst The unsupported catalyst was prepared by the Evaporation Induced Self Assembly (EISA) technique adapted from Chaudhari et al. [11]. Around 1 g of a triblock copolymer (Pluronic P-123, Sigma Aldrich) was dissolved in 16 mL of pure anhydrous ethanol (Greenfield Global Inc.) until a homogeneous solution was obtained. This was followed by adding 1.7 mL of nitric acid (67 −70 wt%, Fisher Scientific) and stirring for complete mixing with the acid. To the copolymer solution, another solution containing 4.5 g of dry gallium(III)nitrate hydrate powder (99.9998 wt% trace metal basis, ACROS Organic, Thermo Fisher Scientific) in 5 mL DI-water and 5 mL of ethanol was added. The solution was stirred for 5 h at 600 rpm at room temperature. The homogeneous, colourless mixture was kept inside a drying oven at 60 °C for 48 h. After that, the dried copolymer-gallium mixture was calcined in a muffle furnace at 650 °C for 6 h at a heating rate of 1 °C min−1 in which the copolymer was burned, and the gallium-precursor was converted to Ga2O3. 2.1.2 Supported catalyst Ordered mesoporous silica (SBA-15) was synthesized as described in Dutta et al. [12]. Around 4 g of a triblock copolymer (Pluronic P-123, Sigma Aldrich) was dissolved by stirring (600 rpm for 5 h) in 95 mL of deionized water until a homogeneous solution was obtained. To this solution, 4 mL of hydrochloric acid (HCl, 37 wt%, Fisher Scientific) was added and stirred for about 15 min at a temperature of 38 °C. Then 9.5 mL of tetraethoxysilane (TEOS, 99.9%, Alfa Aesar) was added. The resulting mixture was stirred at 600 rpm for an additional 24 h at 38 °C to complete TEOS hydrolysis and precipitation of silica. The mixture was then placed inside a closed polypropylene digestion DigiTUBEs (SCP science) and kept inside an oven at 100 °C for 48 h for hydrothermal treatment. After cooling, the white powder was separated by filtration and washed with deionized water 5–6 times, followed by overnight drying at 60 °C. Finally, SBA-15 was obtained by calcining the dried solid at 550 °C for 5 h at a heating rate of 1 °C min−1. Supported catalysts were synthesized by incipient wetness impregnation of SBA-15 with a gallium-containing precursor. Typically, 1 g of SBA-15 was impregnated with 1 g of gallium (III) nitrate hydrate in a 4.5 mL aqueous solution. The almost wet solid was left for 24 h at room temperature, followed by drying overnight at 70 °C. The dried solid was then calcined at 550 °C for 5 h at a heating rate of 1 °C min−1 in a muffle furnace to produce gallium oxide inside SBA-15 with a target Ga loading of 16 wt%. 2.1.3 Nitrides Unsupported and supported nitride catalysts (denoted GaN and GaN/SBA-15), as well as nitridated support (N-SBA-15), were prepared via nitridation of the parent sample with anhydrous ammonia (NH3, 99.99%, MEGS Specialty Gases). The nitridation was carried out before the activity test in the same packed bed reactor. By doing so, exposure to air and moisture was avoided. A quartz tube (7 mm ID × 335 mm long) with a 15 − 40 µ frit at one end was used as the reactor inside a vertical tube furnace (Mellen Company). The nitridation was done at 700 °C for the Ga2O3/SBA-15 and 750 °C for the Ga2O3 sample using 15 mL N min−1 NH3 and 1 mL N min−1 Ar (99.999%, AirLiquid) for 11 h. Both gases were mass flow controlled with calibrated Vögtlin red-y smart controller (±5% accuracy for NH3 and ± 0.3% accuracy for Ar, Switzerland). Ga2O3 nitridation with NH3 to GaN occurs via amorphous gallium oxynitrides intermediates, in which the N–H dissociation from the NH2* to NH* and H2O release are rate-limiting steps [15]. 2.2 Activity measurements 2.2.1 Isotope labelling experiments For isotope labelling experiments, CH3D (98 atom% D, Sigma-Aldrich), 13CH4 (99 atom%, Sigma-Aldrich), and CD4 (99.8 atom% D, Sigma-Aldrich LOT TA0544V) were used. The same micro-catalytic packed bed reactor was used as described above with the following operating conditions: 700 °C at 1 bar, 80% CH4 (corresponding isotope gas) in Ar with a total flow rate of 5 mL N min−1, catalyst loading of 100 mg. Again, all gases were mass flow controlled with calibrated Vögtlin red-y smart controller (±0.3% accuracy). Since the mass spectrometer (MS) was not calibrated for the isotope products (e.g., D2, HD, C2D4, C3D6, C6D6), the results are presented as the normalized mass spectra signal with respect to the internal standard Ar. The isotope gas cylinders contain the following impurities: • CD4 (O2 < 50 ppmV; N2 < 50 ppmV; CO2 < 15 ppmV; C2H6 = 30 ppmV) • CH3D (Air < 3845 ppmV; CO2 < 15 ppmV; C2H6 = 112 ppmV) • 13CH4 (O2 < 30 ppmV; N2 < 50 ppmV; 13CO2 = 713 ppmV; CO = 57 ppmV) 2.2.2 Kinetic experiments Kinetic experiments were done with 100 mg of supported GaN/SBA-15 catalyst within a temperature range of 650 − 710 °C at a total pressure of 1 barabs. The total gas flow rate was set to 5 mLN min−1 with 10 − 80 vol% CH4 (99.999%, Linde) in Ar (99.999%, Air Liquid), which were mass flow controlled (MFC) using calibrated Vögtlin red-y smart controller (± 0.3% accuracy, Switzerland). The reactor outlet and transfer lines to the calibrated mass spectrometer (MS, Pfeiffer GSD 301) were electrically heated at 200 °C to avoid condensation of the organic components (i.e., C6H6, C7H8, C10H8). Before heating, the catalyst was purged with Ar (25 mL N min−1) for 1 h, then heated to reaction temperature at a rate of 5 °C min−1, and subsequently, CH4 was added. Based on a detailed mass spectrum analysis and calibration factors, the CH4 conversion and product molar flow rates (µmol min−1 gGa −1) were determined as a function of time on stream. Besides hydrogen (H2) and ethylene (C2H4), other hydrocarbons such as propylene (C3H6) and benzene (C6H6) were detected (see Fig. 1) and quantified. The CH4 conversion (%) to hydrocarbons was calculated based on the gaseous carbon products (Eq. 1). (1) X C H 4 = ∑ ν i · n ˙ i n ˙ C H 4 , in · 100 Where n ̇ i denotes the molar flow rate in µmol min−1, while ν i denotes the number of carbon atoms in the i th species in the product stream (i.e., C2H4, C3H6, CO2 and C6H6), the denominator represents the molar flow of methane in the feed (µmol min−1). The conversion closely represents the percentage (%) of carbon (C) converted to hydrocarbons, not coke. Results reported in this work for the methane activation were consistent within 5% of C and H elemental balances. The turnover frequency (TOF) could not be calculated as the active surface area (number of active sites) could not be determined via standard chemisorption using H2, CH4 and CH4–TPD techniques. H2 and CH4 did not chemisorb at low temperatures (25 − 45 °C). In addition, NH3–TPD was performed within this study, but again the number of active sites (i.e., Ga–N) could not be determined because a significant amount of NH3 adsorbed on the nitridated support (N-SBA-15) and was indistinguishable from the amount adsorbed on Ga–N over GaN/SBA-15, see supplemental information for more details and Fig. S1. Therefore, the product formation rate is based on (µmol min−1 gGa −1) and not per active surface area. Since the amount of Ga was not changed in the catalyst synthesis, the reaction rate based on the mass of Ga is directly proportional to the rate based on the active surface area. The list of kinetic experiments conducted, including repeat runs, is shown in Table S1 (supplemental information). 2.3 Catalyst characterization 2.3.1 13C Solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (SS‐NMR) The NMR spectra were acquired on a Varian VNMRS spectrometer operating at 399.8 MHz for 1H and 100.5 MHz for 13C using a 4 mm double-resonance Varian Chemagnetics T3 probe (Agilent, Santa Clara, CA, USA). Approximately 15 mg of spent sample were packed into rotors using boron nitride inserts and spun between 10 and 15 kHz. The recycle delay used was 5 s for all experiments, and a contact time of 1500 µs of approximately 60 kHz was used for the cross-polarization (CP) experiments. Between 6000 and 12,000 scans were acquired for each experiment. SPINAL− 64 decoupling at an rf-field of 45 kHz was applied during acquisition. The catalyst samples used for the NMR analysis were obtained by CH4 activation (at least 2 h run at 700 °C) using CH4 and 13CH4 over GaN/SBA-15 and GaN. Post CH4 activation, the spent catalyst in the reactor was first purged with Ar (5 mL N min−1) for 30 min at 700 °C. After that, the reactor was cooled to room temperature overnight under Ar (15 mL N min−1). The MS confirmed the complete removal of methane (CH4 or 13CH4) from the gas stream (Ar). The spent catalysts were collected and stored in an Ar-filled vial inside an Ar-filled desiccator before they were used for collecting the NMR spectra. 2.3.2 In-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) Diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS) spectra were recorded on a Thermo Scientific™ Nicolet™ iS50 FTIR Spectrometer equipped with a standard diffuse-reflectance attachment in the range of 400 − 6000 cm−1, with a resolution of 4 cm−1 and 250 scans for signal accumulation and MCT detector. For the in-situ measurements, a Harrick Praying Mantis™ high-temperature reaction chamber (with ZnSe window) was used, and the data was analyzed using OMNIC 9.11.706 software. The DRIFTS experiments were carried out with both supported and unsupported catalysts. The catalysts were diluted with potassium bromide (KBr, Infrared grade, Fisher Chemical), which was crushed (< 20 µm), dried overnight at 150 °C and stored inside a desiccator. Around 9.5 mg of supported GaN/SBA-15 (2.5 mg of unsupported GaN) was mixed thoroughly with 14 mg (17.5 mg KBr for GaN) of dried KBr. The catalyst-KBr sample was placed on quartz wool (previously dried overnight at 150 °C, cooled and stored inside the desiccator) inside the high-temperature reaction chamber. The chamber was purged with Ar (99.999%, 10 mL N min−1) for 1 h at room temperature and then heated under Ar (10 mL N min−1) to 650 °C (10 °C min−1) to remove moisture and adsorbed CO2. It was then cooled down (or heated) under Ar (10 mL N min−1) to the initial temperature of the analysis, and the background was collected at this temperature. Subsequently, CH4 gas (99.999%) was introduced into the system. Two studies were carried out after the purging and drying, (1) isothermal DRIFTS at 700 °C and (2) temperature-programmed DRIFTS (TP-DRIFTS) from 400 − 700 °C. In the second approach, the experiment was started at 400 °C. The CH4 flow rate was 2.0 mLN min− 1, and the Ar flow rate was 0.5 mL N min−1. After 30 min, CH4 was stopped, and the Ar flow rate was gradually increased to 15 mL N min−1. The Ar flow was held for about 25 min to ensure that CH4 had been removed completely (confirmed via MS and the IR spectra). After that, the temperature was increased by 50 °C increments (20 °C min−1 heating rate) under Ar atmosphere. Around 10 min of stabilization time was given before starting CH4 again. The IR spectra were collected continuously during this whole time (starting from the background collection). To confirm that the surface intermediates were forming on the catalysts, the support (SBA-15) and nitridated support (N-SBA-15) were also tested at 700 °C with 80% CH4 in Ar (2.0 mL N min−1 CH4 and 0.5 mL N min−1 Ar). The obtained spectra were subtracted by the background. The background spectra were obtained at each temperature for the temperature-programmed DRIFTS. All IR absorbance spectra are reported as log(1/R), where R is the sample reflectance, which is the intensity measured under reaction conditions divided by the reference spectrum (i.e., only Ar-feed). 2.3.3 Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) Temperature-programmed oxidation (TPO) coupled with mass spectrometry was carried out for the fresh and spent catalysts to determine the carbon deposited during methane activation (during synthesis for the fresh catalyst). Around 55 mg of supported catalyst was placed in a fixed bed reactor and purged with Ar (20 mL N min−1) for 1 h at room temperature. The catalyst was then dried (under Ar flow) for 2 h at 150 °C, followed by cooling to 70 − 75 °C. Then air (Ultra Zero Air, MEGS Specialty Gases, 20 mL N min−1) was introduced (mixing with Ar at 1.5 mL N min−1) and heated to 950 °C with a heating rate of 2.5 °C min−1. The product gas at the reactor outlet was electrically heated to 150 °C and analyzed by a mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer Omnistar GSD 301) calibrated for CO2 (m/z = 44). The gas flow rates were controlled by respective calibrated Vögtlin red-y smart controllers ( ± 0.3% accuracy, Switzerland). A comprehensive catalyst characterization including physisorption data, X-Ray Diffraction (XRD) analyses, high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HRTEM) with energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) has been published in [10,12,14]. 3 Kinetic parameter estimation and model discrimination 3.1 Model assumptions and reaction mechanisms For the parameter estimation, a simple one-dimensional model was developed based on the differential approach as R C 2 H 4 = n ˙ C 2 H 4 / m cat = r obs . Where R C 2 H4 is the observed ethylene formation rate (molC2H4 s−1 gcat −1), n ˙ C 2 H 4 is the molar flow rate of the produced C2H4 (mol s−1), m is the amount of catalyst (gcat) and r obs is the assumed reaction rate expression. As the overall reaction is thermodynamically limited (i.e., at 700 °C, the maximum methane conversion is 4.1%), the observed rate (r obs ) must be sufficiently far from the equilibrium to represent the forward rate (r). The analysis is based on the approach-to-equilibrium (Eq. 2), (2) r = r obs 1 − η where η is the reaction quotient divided by the equilibrium constant (see details in the supplemental material equation S1). For the current experimental conditions, η values of less than 0.04 were determined. Hence, the observed rate was equal to the forward rate and herein reflects the intrinsic catalytic event far away from the chemical equilibrium and without mass transfer limitation. Additional model assumptions were steady-state, isothermal, no pressure loss, and no pore diffusion limitations. The latter assumption was checked by calculating the Weisz criteria (supplemental material Section 3.2 and Fig. S6). Five rate equations based on distinct assumptions were proposed (supplemental material sections 3.4), which can be represented as a general Langmuir-Hinshelwood (LH) rate expression (Eq. 3) with different exponents (α, β, γ) and CHx surface intermediates (K x ), see Table 1. (3) r = k r K x ⋅ p C H 4 α 1 + K x ⋅ p C H 4 β γ The first two models are power laws with zero order and alpha order in methane (Table 1), respectively. For model 2, alpha is a fitted parameter. The third and fourth models are Langmuir-Hinshelwood rate expressions, with rate-determining steps (RDS) being the first and second C−H bond cleavage, respectively. Here K x presents the adsorption constant of the CH4* or CH3* (entries 3 and 4 in Table 1). In model 5, instead of assuming a generic active site (indicated by *), [Ga·N] has been assumed as one active site containing two different entities, Ga3+ and N3−, which are Lewis acid-base pairs that enable the dissociation of CH4 into an alkyl (CH3) species and hydrogen (H) species. This has been confirmed by DFT modelling, which shows that CH4 dissociatively adsorbs on GaN, in which the carbon in CH4 is attracted towards the gallium (Ga3+) and the hydrogen towards the nitrogen (N3−) denoted as H3C−Ga·N−H [11]. The rate-determining step for model 5 is assumed to be the second C−H cleavage (H3C−Ga·N−H → H2C−Ga·N + H2(g) [11], see entry 5 in Table 1). 3.2 Parameter estimation and model discrimination The parameters to be estimated were α the reaction order for model 2, the pre-exponential factors of the reaction rate and adsorption coefficients as well as the corresponding activation energies and heats of adsorptions, which can be described by the modified Arrhenius’ and van’t Hoff’s equations, respectively, with a finite reference temperature T ref, set to 973.15 K (see Eqs. 4 and 5). (4) k j = exp θ k , j ⋅ exp θ E , j 1 − T ref T (5) K i = exp θ K , i ⋅ exp θ H , i 1 − T ref T The parameters were chosen as θ k , j = ln k j , T ref and θ K , i = ln K i , T ref to assure non-negative values of the pre-exponential factors according to the chemical theory. Activation energies and heat of adsorptions are estimated by introducing a dimensionless energy parameter θ E , j = E A , j R ⋅ T ref and θ H , i = Δ H i R ⋅ T ref , respectively. T Data points at all temperature and pressure levels have been evaluated simultaneously using the GREGPLUS solver within the software package Athena Visual Studio® v 14.2 developed by Stewart and Caracotsios [16] to determine the kinetic parameters. The model discrimination was based on the posterior probability share shown in Eq. 6. (6) π M k | D , ε = p M k | D , ε ∑ k p M k | D , ε Where p(M k |D,ε) is the posterior probability of each model; see more details in [17,18]. The apparent activation energies based on the observed rate of ethylene formation at methane partial pressure of 0.8 bar and 0.2 bar were determined from the slope of the linearized Arrhenius equation. 4 Results and discussion 4.1 Kinetic isotope effect The main products during the non-oxidative CH4 coupling over GaN/SBA-15 at 700 °C were H2 (m/z = 2) and C2H4 (m/z = 27, 28), while C3H6 (m/z = 41, 42) and C6H6 (m/z = 51, 52, 78) were observed in minor quantities (i.e., 1–2 orders of magnitude smaller) as shown in Fig. 1. The mass spec signal for the mass-to-charge ratio from 1 to 90 was obtained and analyzed for each temperature-programmed surface reaction mass spectrometry experiment. The mass spectra were normalized with the internal standard Ar (m/z = 40). Each of the isotope gas cylinders (CH4, 13CH4, CD4, CH3D) contained some traces of N2, H2, CO, CO2 and C2H6; the normalized signals of these trace elements were subtracted from the subsequent analyses of the hydrogen and ethylene groups depicted in Fig. 2. In detail, Fig. 2A−D illustrates the normalized mass spectra of the methane group (m/z = 15–20) for GaN/SBA-15 exposed to different methane isotopes. The absence of mass spectra signal within the initial 5 min was due to the residence time effect. For the CH4, CD4 and 13CH4 experiments, the observed mass spectra responses in the presence of the catalyst corresponded to the normal ionization in a quadrupole mass spectrometer, as shown in the light grey shaded area of Fig. 2A, C and D. For CH3D, however, the mass spectra response differed significantly (Fig. 2B), indicating the H and D exchange stipulated over the catalyst. This phenomenon of proton exchange was also reported by Sattler et al. [19]. Normal ionization in the quadrupole mass spectrometer of CH3D (m/z = 17) resulted in CH2D and CH3 with a mass-to-charge ratio of m/z = 16 and m/z = 15, respectively. In the presence of GaN/SBA-15, the normalized signal of m/z = 17 (CH3D, CHD2) was much smaller and equal to m/z = 16 (CH2D, CH4), which was about the same as for the feed. The m/z = 15 (CH3, CHD) signals increased significantly and new signals at m/z = 18 (CH2D2) and m/z = 19 (CHD3) appeared. This kinetic isotope effect (KIE) behaviour was slightly different over unsupported GaN, as illustrated in Fig. S3B. Here, after 1 h, the signals associated with CH2D2 and CHD3 (m/z = 18 and 19) and CH3 or CHD (m/z = 15) increased, reached a maximum and then decreased asymptotically to the normalized feed signal. Fig. 2E − H illustrates the mass spectra of the hydrogen group (m/z = 2–4: H2, HD, and D2). For both the CH4 and 13CH4 experiments, the H2 (m/z = 2) formation rates were similar, while for the partially and fully deuterated methane (CH3D and CD4), the hydrogen group consisted of H2 (m/z = 2), HD (m/z = 3) and D2 (m/z = 4) with different normalized intensities (Fig. 1 E and H). The H2 (m/z = 2) formation rate from the CH3D experiment was 30% lower than from CH4, while no H2 signal for CD4 was observed. The D2 (m/z = 4) signal intensity from the CD4 experiments was 44% lower than the intensity for H2 from CH4 experiments, indicating that it was easier to break the C−H bond than the C−D bond, with a corresponding ratio of the rate constant k C−H /k C−D = 1.8. These values agree with the literature that reports ratios between 1.60 − 1.89 [20]. This KIE was also observed for the CH3D experiments with a similar ratio of k C−H /k C−D = 2.0, see the proposed steps in Scheme 1. Reactions k 1 and k 7 refer to the fast C−H bond scissions, k 2 to the slow C−D bond scission and reactions k 6 , k 8 , and k 10 to the deuterium addition. The measured signal of m/z = 3 (HD) for the CD4 experiments was most likely due to hydrogen in < 0.2 vol% CH4 and 30 ppmV C2H6 in CD4. If H2, DH, and D2, were being formed over the supported catalysts, adsorbed CD x species should be present because the first step of activation is the formation of D3C−Ga·N−D. The normalized mass spectra for the mass-to-charge ratio of m/z = 28 (possible species C2H4, CO, and N2) are illustrated in Fig. 2I−L. Since no m/z = 28 signal was observed for the CD4 run (Fig. 2 K), N2 formation (decomposition of GaN), as well as CO formation, can be excluded, which was confirmed in [8–10]. However, for the 13CH4 run, a significant amount of 13CO was produced (m/z = 29) because the gas cylinder contained around 710 ppmV of 13CO2 (m/z = 45). Upon reaction with 13CH4 at 700 °C, all 13CO2 was converted via the dry reforming (Fig. S2). The added contribution to m/z = 28 signal can be associated with the formation of C2H4 since the gas cylinder contained 1 atom% carbon 12 (e.g., CH4). The carbon- and deuterium-labelled surface intermediates such as 13CH3* , 13CH2* , CD3* and CD2* seemed to be more strongly adsorbed than CH3* and CH2* species, as only the ethylene signal of m/z = 28 (C2H4) was observed. No significant mass spec signals for m/z = 30–32 (13C2H4, C2H2D2, and C2D4) were detected. The corresponding carbon coupling may also have been much slower, indicated by an additional time delay of 5 min over the residence time delay. The cleavage of the first C−H (13C−H and C−D) bond dissociation is not the rate-determining step because H2, HD, and D2 appeared immediately after the residence time delay (Fig. 2E − H). Post C–H bond activation and formation of CH3* and H* , ethylene formation has three elementary steps: (1) formation of CH2* (or CHD, 13CH2) from CH3* , (2) dimerization of CH2* (or CHD, 13CH2) to form C2H4 (or C2H2D2, 13CH2), and (3) desorption of ethylene. The first step is the rate-determining step, as predicted by the DFT calculations [11]. Non-detection of labelled ethylene (e.g., C2D4 and 13C2H4) over GaN/SBA-15 indicates that the adsorbed surface intermediate might have high negative adsorption energy, and the desorption energy was also very high (positive). Iglesia et al. [21] also did not detect any labelled products during non-oxidative methane-propane (13CH4 − C3H8) conversion over ZSM5 at 500 °C. They suggested that the non-oxidative conversion of CH4 to higher hydrocarbons on solid acids was limited by elementary steps that occur after the initial activation of C−H bonds, which was also true for our system (formation of CH2*, CHD*, dimerization, and C2H4 desorption). For the unsupported GaN samples, the normalized mass spectra analysis showed similar behaviours (Fig. S3). In addition, the unsupported catalyst produced more benzene than the supported catalyst (see Fig. S5 vs. S4), confirmed by a previous study [12]. Over GaN, the benzene isotopes from CD4 (m/z = 84, C6D6) and 13CH4 (m/z = 84, 13C6H6) were similar and slightly lower than from CH4 (Fig. S5A vs. S5D). Exposing the GaN sample to CH3D also showed a clear kinetic isotope effect for the benzene group, as mass signals from m/z = 79 (C6H5D) to m/z = 82 (C6H2D4) were detected (Fig. S5B). For the supported catalyst (GaN/SBA-15), only the main mass signal for m/z = 79 was observed, which was by a factor of 100 smaller (Fig. S4). The supported catalysts favour the formation of alkenes, while the unsupported catalyst produced a significant amount of aromatics besides the alkenes. As stated above, no C2-related isotopes were observed during the CD4 experiments; however, after switching to CH4, ethylene from CH4 (m/z = 28, Fig. 3A) and isotopes corresponding to C2H2D2 (m/z = 30) and C2HD3 (m/z = 31) were observed (Fig. 3C and D). The C2HD3 and C2H2D2 species diminished after 20 min and 40 min, respectively. This indicates that CD3* and CD2* surface species are formed during the CD4 run, which is also confirmed by the formation of D2 (m/z = 4, Fig. 2G). These surface intermediates react more easily with CH3* and CH2* to C2 than with other CD2* species to form C2D4. It seems that the adsorbed CD3* and CD2* species were replaced (facilitated desorption [22]) by CHx (replacement adsorption, defined in [23]) during the CH4 activation cycle, which led to the formation of mixed isotopes C2H2D2 (m/z = 30) and C2HD3 (m/z = 32) a few minutes before to the formation of C2H4 (m/z = 28) (compare maximum in Fig. 2). The absence of the m/z = 29 signal suggests that the last two C−D bonds were not cleaved, or no H/D isotope exchange occurred. (Fig. 3B). 4.2 NMR The spent catalysts obtained after 13 CH4 activation experiments were analyzed via 13C solid-state nuclear magnetic resonance (SS‐NMR) o identify adsorbed carbonaceous species. The 13C signals presented in Fig. 4 are the result of the surface-based C−H bond activation of methane and not due to gaseous or physisorbed methane, which have been removed. Methyl species (−CH3), indicated by a chemical shift at − 9 ppm [24], were the predominant adsorbed carbon intermediate on the GaN/SBA-15 catalyst (Fig. 4). This was also confirmed via 13C NMR over Ga-modified ZSM zeolites, which show Ga−CH3 shift between − 1.8 and − 16.2 ppm [24]. For the unsupported GaN catalyst, on the other hand, aromatic surface species, indicated by a broad peak around 125 ppm [25,26], were predominant. These species are known to form polynuclear species or coke, which explains the higher amount of coke per gram of catalyst. For the supported GaN/SBA-15 catalyst, the intensity for the aromatic species was much smaller, which explains the higher C2H4 and lower C6H6 selectivities observed for the methane activation conducted over supported than over unsupported catalysts (per gram of Ga [12]). Unsupported catalysts are nearly non-porous. The surface GaN on these are readily accessible to CH4, and they also form the active sites for C−C bond coupling to form higher hydrocarbons above C2H4. This C−C coupling beyond C3 becomes limited in GaN/SBA-15 due to the dispersion of GaN inside the SBA-15 pores [12]. 4.3 DRIFTS During CH4 adsorption, very strong adsorption peaks referring to the νC−H and δC−H bands of the gaseous CH4 appeared at 3015 cm−1 and 1305 cm−1 (see Fig. 5, line CH4 no Ar purge), which masked the spectra of the adsorbed surface species. Therefore, the sample was purged with Ar after CH4 exposure to remove the gaseous methane as well as the physisorbed surface species leaving the strongly chemisorbed surface intermediates that are illustrated with the dark blue spectra for the GaN/SBA-15 catalyst in Fig. 5 (CH4 after Ar purge). The subsequent discussion on the DRIFTS results is based on the adsorbed species observed during the Ar purge, which lasted for around 0.5 h. It took around 20–25 min for the characteristic methane peak at 3015 cm−1 to vanish completely. Fig. 6 illustrates and compares the DRIFT spectra observed over the support (SBA-15), nitridated support (N-SBA-15), GaN/SBA-15 and unsupported GaN catalysts after exposing them to 80% CH4 for 1 h at 700 °C, followed by Ar purge. From left to right in Fig. 6 and Table 2 for peak identification, the band at 3450 − 3400 cm−1 (appearing in the nitridated support N-SBA-15 and as a shoulder GaN/SBA-15) could be assigned to primary amine N−H stretching vibrations (medium intensity)[27,28]. It has been shown that the silanol groups in SBA-15 are converted to primary (NH2) and secondary (NH) silanamine functional groups ( ≡ Si–OH → ≡ Si–NH2 → ≡ Si–NH–Si ≡ ) at 700 °C in the presence of NH3 [28]. The parent SBA-15 sample did not exhibit any N−H bonds related peaks. NH3−TPD confirms this, as illustrated by a huge desorption peak for the nitridated samples (Fig. S1). The peak at 3215 cm−1 (broad shoulder in GaN and GaN/SBA-15) could be attributed to the N−H stretch (secondary amine) formed during the CH4 activation over GaN as H3C−Ga·N−H. The support SBA-15 and nitridated support N-SBA-15 were not active towards the non-oxidative methane coupling and did not exhibit characteristic peaks associated with this N−H stretch (3215 cm−1) and any adsorbed carbon species such as CH3, C−H, aromatic, and alkene CC bonds, which were only visible for the GaN containing catalysts (Fig. 6). However, the support exhibited broad double peaks at around 2020 cm−1 and 1880 cm−1 and a stronger peak at 1360 cm−1 are due to the inorganic structure of SBA-15. GaN and GaN/SBA-15 showed characteristic peaks around the same wavenumbers ( ± 15 cm−1). The band, 3150 − 3000 cm−1, can be attributed to sp 2 =C−H stretching (alkenes), with medium intensity, but also for C−H stretch in aromatics [27]. The 1600 − 1760 cm−1 wavenumbers are typical for alkenes (isolated CC, vinyl), with weak to strong intensities. The N−H bending vibration (primary amine) can also be observed in this region. Methylene (>CH2) has a characteristic band at 1500 − 1400 cm−1 (deformation with medium intensity) and 1380 − 1160 cm−1 (wagging with medium intensity). Symmetric bending vibration in CH3 could be assigned to 1405 cm−1 (medium-strong [27]). The vinyl hydrocarbons (−CH=CH2) also exhibit a medium intensity around 1400 cm−1 for CH2 in-plane deformation vibration and scissoring. The wavenumber near 1240 cm−1 could be attributed to C−H in-plane bending in aromatics. A weaker intensity in the band, 1250 − 1230 cm−1, could also be assigned to =C−H in-plane deformation vibrations in monosubstituted benzenes (e.g., toluene). For the GaN sample, the ratio of the peaks at around 3100 cm−1 to 1400 cm−1 is much larger than for the GaN/SBA-15 sample, reflecting the higher number of aromatics than olefinic species for the unsupported GaN catalysts. McKean et al. [29] assigned 1440 and 1205 cm−1 for vibration in Ga(CH3)3, which are very close to our results. Socrates [27] assigned a medium to weak intensity for Ga−CH3 at 1240 cm−1. These adsorbed species substantiate the mechanism proposed by DFT calculations. The first step is the formation of Ga−CH3 (1240 cm−1, 1400 cm−1) and N−H (secondary amine at 3215 cm−1). This is followed by the formation of Ga−CH2; the two CH2 combine to form C2H4 and H2. Temperature-programmed DRIFTS (TP-DRIFTS) were performed to establish the minimum temperature required to form these adsorbed species. The DRIFT spectra indicated the formation of adsorbed species from 400 °C for both supported and unsupported catalysts ( Fig. 7). The olefinic species (∼1400 cm−1) started from 500 °C and 650 °C for the GaN/SBA-15 and GaN catalysts, respectively. In contrast, the appearance of aromatic species (3000 −3150 cm−1) started from 600 °C onwards. DRIFTS experiments with CH4 and CD4 confirmed the presence of CH x and CD x species, as discussed above. DRIFTS measurements were carried out on GaN/SBA-15 at 700 °C with CH4 and CD4. First, CH4 was passed over the catalyst for 1 h, then purged with Ar. The spectrum was recorded ( Fig. 8 dark blue line labelled CH4), which was followed by feeding CD4 for 1 h, and the spectrum was collected after Ar purge (blue line labelled CH4-CD4). Upon addition of CD4, some small and new peaks appeared: the peak at 2750 cm−1 corresponds to O−D formed by the exchange between SBA-15′s silanol group’s (Si−OH) with deuterium of CD4 [30,31]. The small peaks between ∼2670 cm−1 and 2500 cm−1 are most likely to N−D formed by alkyl adsorption of D3C δ−D δ+ on Ga3+N3− as the N−H bond (∼3200 cm−1) is substituted by the N−D [32]. For fully deuterated methane (CD4), these two peaks are at slightly higher wavenumber (+15 cm−1). Adsorption bands at 2250 cm−1, 2220 cm−1 and 2120 cm−1 may correspond to νs and νas (CD3) as suggested in [33,34]. The peaks at 3140 cm−1 and 3090 cm−1 may be associated with −CC−H stretching vibration in aromatics and alkenes as the CD4 gas cylinder contained < 0.2 vol% CH4. But mixed isotope surface species can not be ruled out. 4.4 Kinetic experiment Fig. 9 illustrates the methane conversion and ethylene rate as the function of methane partial pressure (0.1–0.8 bar) at 700 °C and 1 bar total pressure. As expected, the conversion decreased with the increasing partial pressure, which was also predicted by thermodynamic calculations (solid line in Fig. 9 A) using HSC Chemistry v9. Even though the minor components (C3H6 and C6H6) were 100 − 1000 lower than C2H4, their yields also had the same trend (inset of Fig. 9 A). The apparent order of the reaction was estimated to be close to zero-order, as depicted in Fig. 9B. The fast dissociative chemisorption of methane leads to fast occupancy of the active sites. The amount of unoccupied active sites is inversely proportional to the methane partial pressure, which means a higher rate at lower partial pressures. It is also possible that a lower surface coverage of adsorbed Ga−CH3 lowers the carbon deposition by preventing long-chain, cyclic, aromatic C−C coupling. This was also reported by Guo et al. [8], where single-site separated Fe atoms prevented C−C coupling from forming coke. The influence of the reaction temperature on the ethylene and coke formation rate in the range of 680–720 °C is illustrated in Fig. S7. For a methane partial pressure of 0.8 bar, an apparent activation energy of E A = 24.8 ± 4.8 kJ mol−1 was estimated, whereas, for 0.2 bar, a slightly higher value of E A = 28.7 ± 5.4 kJ mol−1 was estimated. Similar observed activation energies (25 −37 kJ mol−1) were reported for the CH4 activation over silica-supported Ru catalysts and NiO/Ni(100)] systems [35,36]. For the rate of coke formation, an apparent activation energy of 402 ± 47 kJ mol−1 was determined (Fig. S6B). It was in the range of reported values for the thermal decomposition of methane, 347 − 430 kJ mol−1 [37]. The apparent activation energy for the C2H4 formation rate was 15 times lower, indicating that the C2H4 formation governs the overall methane conversion rate (Fig. S7C), typically observed for parallel reactions. Albeit the C2H4 formation rate was low at 660 °C, its selectivity was above 90%, which decreased to 70% at 700 °C and 720 °C. As expected, at higher temperatures, the coke formation became prominent, reducing the rate of C2H4 formation. 4.5 Parameter estimation and model discrimination The results of the model discrimination showed that models #4 and #5 have the highest posterior probability share of 42.6% and 40.2%, respectively ( Table 3), which makes them statistically superior to the other models. Model #1, a simple Power law rate expression with zero order in CH4, has a zero percent probability. In contrast, model #2, with an estimated order of 0.14 ( Table 4), has a probability share of 14% to represent the observed data. This is much higher than for model #3, which assumes that the first C−H bond cleavage is the rate-limiting step (i.e., CH4* + *→ CH3* + H*). For our catalyst and operating conditions, model #4, assuming the second C−H bond cleavage to be rate determining with the formation of the CH2* intermediate (i.e., CH3* + *→ CH2* + H*) fits the data best, which reaffirms our DFT results [11]. Over other catalysts, it is assumed that the first C−H bond cleavage is rate-determining [8]. The corresponding LH-rate expression is shown in Eq. (7). (7) r obs = k r · K x · p C H 4 1 + K x · p C H 4 2 The best fit could also be ascertained from the objective function, which is the sum of squares of the residuals and the R-square values. Model #3 has the lowest objective function (3.16 ×10−13) and the highest R-square value (0.953). Table 4 summarizes the estimated kinetic parameters with the highest posterior density (HPD) interval and the normalized covariance matrix. The covariance matrix in multi-parameter estimation is an important criterion for evaluating the parameters’ quality and the model. The elements in the normalized covariance matrix E ij are within, where a value of +1 (−1) indicates a strong correlation (anti-correlation) between parameter i and j. A correlation coefficient of +1 means a perfect direct (increasing) linear correlation and a coefficient of −1 is inverse (decreasing) linear anti-correlation. K x and k r as well as E a and ∆ H in models #4 and #5, have a relatively strong anti-correlation with a greater degree of linear dependence (the correlation coefficients are close to −0.8). This was expected because strong adsorption means a slower rate of reaction. The HPD interval was rather broad due to the small data size; however, the observed rates agree with the predicted rate for model 4, as illustrated in Fig. 10 (all other models are illustrated in Figs. S8 and S9). The Arrhenius plots are also in good agreement between the experimental and predicted values (Fig. 10 A). The parity plot (Fig. 10B) depicts that all the rates are well within the ε = 10% region, whereas Fig. 10 C illustrates the observed and calculated C2H4 formation rates for the model 4 for each experiment (Table S1). The experiments and kinetic modelling confirmed the proposed reaction pathway for the non-oxidative methane coupling to ethylene over GaN based catalysts. CH4 does not adsorb as a molecule on GaN; it undergoes fast dissociative adsorption. In this first step (R1 in Fig. 11), carbon in CH4 adsorbs on the top side of Ga3+, while one hydrogen in CH4 is attracted towards the N3 − atom resulting in stretching and cleavage of the C−H bond and formation of the methyl (CH3*) surface species. The second C−H bond cleavage (step R2) is much slower and forms methylene (CH2*) surface species on Ga−N hollow sites. The C−C coupling is assumed to proceed via two CH2* surface species adsorbed on adjacent Ga−N hollow sites (see R3), in which CH2* turn toward each other (R4) to form C2H4, which subsequently desorbs (R5). The main difference between the presented reaction pathways to other pathways is that C−C coupling does not yield in the formation of gaseous ethane (C2H6), which is subsequently dehydrogenated to ethylene (C2H4). 5 Conclusions In conclusion, we have gained insight into the CH4 coupling mechanism to C2H4 over GaN catalysts under non-oxidative conditions. In detail, the presence of methyl and methylene surface intermediates on GaN catalysts proposed through DFT modelling has been confirmed by DRIFTS and 13C SS‐NMR measurements. The latter also confirmed that supported GaN/SBA-15 has more aliphatic surface intermediates than unsupported GaN catalyst, which has more aromatics intermediates and coke. Temperature-programmed surface reaction combined mass spectrometry and isotope labelling experiments established that either there was a delay (above residence time) in the formation of mixed isotope products (formed by 13CH4 and CD4). However, the formation of H2 isotopes was delayed only by residence time. This confirms that the first H−CH3 bond cleavage was not rate-determining. The apparent order of the reaction is close to zero in CH4, which indicates fast adsorption and that active sites might always be covered with adsorbed species. The intrinsic activation energy predicted by kinetic modelling and parameter determination from the best-fit model was around 20 kJ mol−1. The most probable kinetic models considered the formation of CH2* from CH3* as the RDS, as predicted by the DFT study. The models predicted the observed rates in excellent agreement with the experimental data. The results provide a comprehensive mechanistic insight into the non-oxidative methane activation of gallium nitride catalyst. They are relevant as well as serve as a basis to understand and develop other metal nitride catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The second C−H bond cleavage in methane to form methylene (CH2*) from methyl (CH3*) is the rate-limiting step for the direct non-oxidative methane coupling to ethylene over gallium-nitride catalysts. Herein, we use isotope labelled experiments, in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS), 13C solid state-NMR, as well as kinetic modelling to elucidate the reaction mechanism. Our experiments showed that supported GaN/SBA-15 had more aliphatic surface intermediates (CH3* and CH2*) than unsupported GaN catalysts, which had higher amounts of aromatics intermediates and coke deposition. Isotope labelling experiments and the kinetic study confirmed that the most likely pathway is via the fast abstraction of the first H from CH4 to form methyl (CH3*) surface intermediates, followed by the slow second C−H bond cleavage to form methylene (CH2*) and subsequent coupling to ethylene. The intrinsic activation energy predicted by kinetic modelling was rather low at around 20 kJ mol−1.
coredata.dc:title: Elucidation of the CH4 coupling mechanism to C2H4 over GaN catalysts under non-oxidative conditions
